Response: The NCSC informs me that it had investigated the matter and that its conclusion was that it was a means whereby Mr Connell would eliminate $350m of his ``non performing'' debts to Rothwells.
What conditions of the settlement between the NCSC and Rothwells were broken by Rothwells?
Response: The NCSC advises that the following conditions of the settlement were broken by Rothwells:

1. Rothwells was to establish a Policy Committee to review the company's activities and determine policy. It was to meet on a regular basis. The new Board of Directors failed to ensure that it met on a regular basis. In fact it met only twice.

2. Rothwells agreed that the new management team would review outstanding loans and the security covering those loans and the likelihood of recovery. It was to inform the NCSC of its conclusions by 28 February 1988. The review and report presented by way of audited accounts as at 31 January 1988, was false and misleading.
3. Mr L. Connell was to commit ``$70 million of his own money to support the company''. In fact by means of a round robin, Rothwells itself later advanced much of this sum to Mr Connell.

4. Rothwells was to implement a new ``Management Restructure and Business Plan'' which set out ``the principal decisions taken that will govern the future of Rothwells''. These included statements that:

(i) ``Rothwells will establish and maintain a match between the maturity of borrowings and assets''. In fact most of the bills and loans were `non-performing' so that the company was not receiving interest or loan repayments in accordance with the repayment schedule. Many of the loans and bills were continually rolled over with interest added so that cash inflows were well below expected levels.

(ii) ``Rothwells will seek investments in hard assets and cash flow''. However a substantial sum of the $370 million injected into Rothwells from the October 1987 rescue package was soon diverted to fund part of the Connell's subordinated loan.

(iii) ``. . . Rothwells will be very conservatively geared''. This statement was made in relation to a summarised balance sheet which showed shareholders funds of approximately $287 million and total assets of approximately $763 million. This information was misleading. Further misleading information was given in the audited accounts for the period ended 31 January 1988. For example the provision for `doubtful debts' was stated as $100 million, however the Dalleagles Portfolio of $350 million was in fact described by the company in July 1988 as `non-performing'.

My question ``How were the non-performing loans with a face value of $350m selected'' was answered ``Unable to say''. However the Interim report states (paragraph 8.01): ``The selected loans were later seen by the commission to be those most closely associated with Connell.''
I ask:
(i) In what way were these loans associated with Connell?
(ii) What proportion of the loans were owing by:
(a) L. R. Connell and Partners
(b) Oakhill Pty Ltd
(c) associated companies?
Response: The NCSC advises:
(i) cross guarantees and inter company loans involving Mr Connell.

(ii) Inter relationships between Mr Connell and his companies on the one hand and Mr Connell's associates, including the ``Pier Street'' group of companies, on the other hand were extremely complex and varied over time. This is the subject of further investigations by the Special Investigator. Of the $350m, $69.2m appears to have been loans to Oakhill Pty Ltd, $1511.7m to the ``Pier Street'' Group of companies, $56.2m to companies associated with Mr Brian Yuill.
The following answers have been provided by the National Companies and Securities Commission to written questions by Senator Durack:
When did the NCSC first decide to investigate Rothwells?
Response: On 17 March 1987 the NCSC commenced an investigation into Vital Technology Ltd. As it progressed, the investigation concentrated on particular conduct of the controllers of Rothwells Ltd.
What allegations/events led to this investigation?

Response: The NCSC received a written complaint about the affairs of Vital Technology Ltd. As the investigation proceeded the NCSC became suspicious that Rothwells and associated companies may have engaged in warehousing and ramping of shares in listed companies.
What stage had the investigation reached prior to the crash of the stock market in October 1987?

Response: Several months before the crash NCSC staff decided to concentrate the investigation on whether Rothwell's dealers licence should be revoked because they suspected, as a result of the investigation, that Rothwells was not operating efficiently, honestly or fairly.
Had the NCSC formed any opinion at that time whether Rothwells should be rescued or allowed to go into liquidation? If so what was its view?

Response: No. The NCSC investigation was not into the financial position of Rothwells; it was into Rothwells' conduct as a licensed dealer. The audited accounts and financial returns of Rothwells did not indicate that the company was in financial difficulties.
Why did the NCSC enter into the settlement with Rothwells at this time?

Response: The objectives of the NCSC had been fully achieved and comprehensive assurances obtained. On the information then known to it, the NCSC formed the view that nothing further could be achieved. Rothwells had agreed to surrender its dealers licence and had further agreed that:
(i) the Chairman, Mr L. R. Connell, would step down as Chairman and from any executive position on Rothwells and other Board changes required by the NCSC would be made;
(ii) the Managing Director, Mr P. Lucas would resign and the NCSC was informed that the Western Australian Government would make available a senior public servant to replace him;
(iii) a new ``Management Restructure and Business Plan'' would be undertaken. It appeared to the NCSC that the Plan addressed the problems which were being investigated by the NCSC;
(iv) an audited statement of Rothwells' financial position would be issued as soon as possible; and
(v) substantial shareholder notices would be lodged to ensure that there was full disclosure to the market of Rothwells shareholdings in listed companies.

After the December 1987 settlement the NCSC, in accordance with Co-operative Scheme practice, referred the material gathered in its investigations to the Western Australian Corporate Affairs Department to consider whether further investigation and/or prosecution of possible criminal offences was warranted.
Was any pressure/persuasion applied by any person, organisation or government in favour of this? If so by whom?

Response: No pressure was applied to or perceived by the NCSC staff who negotiated the settlement. There was a letter to the NCSC staff involved in the negotiations from the Western Australian Government providing a character reference for one member of the then Rothwells Board. As a consequence, the NCSC was persuaded to allow that member to remain on the Board.
Subsequent to the settlement, when did the NCSC again become concerned about Rothwells affairs?

Response: Following the announcement by Rothwells on 15 July 1988 that it proposed to sell a $350 million portfolio of loans to Dalleagles Pty Ltd, the NCSC commenced enquiries directed at Rothwells' financial position.
What were the major reasons for its concerns?

Response: The NCSC was concerned whether and how Dalleagles could finance the purchase of the portfolio of loans as Dalleagles was controlled by Mr Connell and Mr T. F. Hugall; why it was purchasing the portfolio; and whether the shareholders of Rothwells were properly informed in relation to the proposed transaction.
What conditions of the settlement were broken by Rothwells?

Response: The NCSC relied on the audited statement of Rothwells' financial position, which was made public as required by the terms of the settlement, and the resignation of Mr Lucas, and the Board of Management changes which were made in response to the NCSC's requirements. The NCSC had no evidence that the conditions of settlement had been broken until after Rothwells collapsed. However, investigations since the collapse indicate that the conditions of the settlement were honoured at best superficially by the new Rothwells Board.
When did Rothwells first show signs of being in difficulty?
Response: The NCSC first became aware on 15 July 1988 that Rothwells might be in financial difficulty. Until then the NCSC relied on the company's audited financial statements.
Did Rothwells take any steps to disguise these? If so, what steps did it take?
Response: Yes. The NCSC has identified in its interim report the complex steps taken by Rothwells to conceal its true financial position.
Why did Rothwells have so many non-performing loans?
Response:
(a) The controls exercised by management and the Board over the authorisation and servicing of the loans were seriously inadequate.
(b) the risk was exacerbated by poor or no security being taken over most of the loans.
Why were such loans `non-performing'?
Response: No detailed analysis of the loans has been undertaken by the NCSC. This is a matter for the provisional liquidator.
Were all the non-performing loans purchased by Connell from Rothwells in July 1988 for $350 million? If not, how were these loans selected?
Response:
(a) No.
(b) Unable to say.
What was the face value of these loans at the time of their purchase?
What was the market value of these loans at the time?
Response: Difficult to say, but only a small fraction of the face value. Perhaps as little as 10 per cent.
How often did Rothwell's Board of Directors meet?
Response: The evidence is conflicting but it appears that the Board seldom met.
What supervision did it maintain over the affairs of the Company?
Response: The Board of Rothwells appears to have played little part in the conduct of the affairs of the Company.
What was the relationship between Rothwells, LR Connell and Partners and Oakhill Pty Ltd?
Response: Rothwells, LR Connell and Partners and Oakhill Pty Ltd are business concerns in which Mr Connell has or had substantial interests. Their affairs were intertwined.
What were the prime causes of the final collapse of Rothwells?

Response: This question is addressed in the NCSC interim report. A special investigation is also under way. However, the most important single cause of the final collapse of Rothwells was a severe liquidity crisis as a result of the consistent failure of its loan portfolio to perform.
When did the NCSC extend its inquiry into a number of companies associated with Rothwells?
Response: The NCSC's inquiries in 1987 and 1988 addressed a number of companies associated with Rothwells. The number of the companies expanded substantially during 1988.
What was the nature of the association?

Response: The nature of the association varied. The primary association lay in Rothwells acting as financier to the associated companies. Otherwise, the associations emanated from common directorships between the companies funded by Rothwells, common location (such as at 19 Pier Street), or considerable influence in the conduct of their affairs being exercised by individuals associated with Rothwells.
How many such companies are involved in the inquiry?
Response: Approximately 100 companies, of which about 10 are listed companies, are involved, with the degree of involvement varying.
What is the nature of these inquiries and what stage has been reached in respect of them?

Response: Broadly, the purpose of the inquiries is to identify the reasons for the collapse of Rothwells, to identify breaches of the law and to obtain evidence for instigating civil and criminal proceedings where appropriate.
Did Beltech Corporation/Technology purchase Connell's half share in Petrochemical Industries Ltd (PICL) around July 31 1987?
Response: Some evidence indicates that Beltech Technology Pty Ltd acquired Mr Connell's 50 per cent interest in PICL prior to 31 July 1987. This is denied by Mr Connell.
What was the purpose of this transaction?

Response: The NCSC has received evidence that it was intended that the transaction be part of the process of reducing the level of debts owed by interests associated with Mr Connell prior to the 1987 Rothwells audit.
What was the purchase price and how was it funded by Beltech?
Response: It appears that the purchase price was $21.45 million and that it was entirely financed with funds from Rothwells.
What did Beltech do with this newly acquired asset?
Response: Nothing appears to have been done with this asset until in 1988 further transactions took place and the asset was returned to Connell interests.
What value was placed on the interest in PICL in Connell's books of account when it was `recovered' by Connell from Beltech?
Response: The only values of which the NCSC is presently aware are:
(a) September 1986: Mr Connell purchased half share in PICL from Mr Dallas Dempster for $105,000;
(b) July 1987: the sale to Beltech, which has been denied by Mr Connell, was at $21.45 million; and
(c) January 1988: LR Connell and Partners showed the half share in their balance sheet at $75 million.
What was the date of this valuation?
Response: See previous answer.
Has the NCSC discovered any evidence which would justify a valuation of $350 million for this interest.
Response: No.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Estimates Committee met there was grave uncertainty as to whether the report of the NCSC on its investigation of Rothwells Ltd would ever see the light of day in any shape or form. Apparently the Federal Government supported the view taken by the Ministerial Council that this report may have some serious consequences for possible prosecutions and the matter was referred to the special investigator for his opinion. There had been other opinions both for and against that proposition. I am not really quite sure where the Federal Government ended up on that matter but perhaps that is not important now.

SPEECH.PARA: However, what was important was the fact that the findings of the national watchdog on such a major investigation, such a major financial collapse, should have been available for consideration by this or any other Parliament, particularly because of the very close involvement of the State Government with this company, both during its death throes and over a long period. The matter was of great public interest. That is why I felt that the NCSC should have been available to answer questions relating to a number of aspects of its investigation.

I put these questions on notice because it was uncertain whether this report would ever be made available. Before these answers were provided the NCSC's interim report was made public. Certainly that has put a different complexion on the urgency of the matter as I saw it at the time of the Estimates Committee. In fact, the interim report gives a very detailed and very frank account of its investigations of Rothwells' activities and of the major players in this whole sorry episode. So it is rather surprising that there was such a degree of coyness on the part of both State and Federal governments in having this information made available at an earlier stage than did occur.

I do not propose to say much about the very detailed information in the report; that has been the subject of a great deal of publicity and examination. But some of the answers provoked by the questions I asked have thrown a little clearer light on some of the major problems which are still outstanding. The answers to my supplementary questions were, in one or two respects, still a bit coy. I instance a question about a matter which was of great public concern at the time, so it was not an unfair question. At the time of the first rescue of Rothwells, after the crash in 1987, when the Western Australian Government became involved with its guarantee, there was widespread publicity and concern about this matter. I asked the following question:
Was any pressure/persuasion applied by any person, organisation or government in favour of this?
That is, the settlement entered into between the NCSC and Rothwells, which was backed up by the guarantee of the Western Australian Government. I then asked:
If so by whom?
The answer I got stated:

No pressure was applied to or perceived by the NCSC staff who negotiated the settlement. There was a letter to the NCSC staff involved in the negotiations from the Western Australian Government providing a character reference for one member of the then Rothwells Board. As a consequence, the NCSC was persuaded to allow that member to remain on the Board.

Of course, this was pretty important because one matter that was greatly worrying the NCSC was the composition of the Rothwells Board and the influence of certain persons in the conduct of Rothwells. Certainly, the NCSC in its settlement with Rothwells at that time was endeavouring to cope with that problem. I thought the answer was not as frank as I would have expected and was, as I said, somewhat coy. So my first supplementary question asked:
Who is the member of the Rothwells Board who received a character reference from the West Australian Government at the time that the settlement with the NCSC was being negotiated in October 1987?
The response to that question stated:
The NCSC advises that it was Mr W. A. Burgess who had been a director of Rothwells since 1982.
His connections with the whole affair are now set out in the report. Who signed this character reference on behalf of the Western Australian Government? The response was:
The NCSC advises that it was signed by Mr Brian Burke MLA.

That response is still a little coy because Mr Burke played the leading role, as the Premier of Western Australia, in having this settlement brought about. We have clear evidence of the very close and direct involvement of the then Premier of Western Australia, Mr Brian Burke, in the settlement on behalf of one of the directors of Rothwells. I think that answer does give some indication of the lack of full information provided to this Parliament-information which I would have expected to have been provided in the first place.

However, what I am really concerned about-and what is still a matter of great concern, particularly to Western Australia, although it should be of great concern to this Parliament as well-is the financial impact of a lot of those Western Australian Government decisions on the ability of the Western Australian Government to perform its ordinary obligations. I would have thought that this would be of interest to the Commonwealth Government because, in a sense, it has the ultimate responsibility for providing finance for all States so that they can carry out their obligations. The Western Australian Government made a commitment in about July last year, when the final collapse of Rothwells became imminent, to invest in the Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd project in Kwinana in Western Australia. The leading player in the Rothwells collapse, Mr Laurie Connell, received $350m for his half share in the plant. As I said, an agreement was entered into in about the middle of last year. That amount of $350m which was made available to Mr Connell enabled him to pay an amount of money to Rothwells, the beneficiaries of which were largely, as we have now discovered, the Bond Corporation and the Western Australian Government itself. It would be remarkable if those events were not tied together. However, I am not claiming at this stage that there is any direct evidence that they were tied together. The question must obviously be posed: Were they tied together? Hopefully, that will be a matter for further investigation.

What has always intrigued me, and no doubt many other people, is how this valuation of $350m for a half share in the petrochemical plant was ever arrived at, especially as the other partner, Mr Dempster, received only $50m for his half share. So Mr Connell's half share was valued at seven times the value of the other half share-another very strange circumstance. I asked some questions on that matter. Again the answers I received were a little coy, even though the interim report had been received. The interim report went a long way towards providing answers, or at least pointing out how this figure of $350m was arrived at. However, some further extraordinary information was provided which I think is pretty much on the public record. I asked:
What value was placed on the interest in the Petrochemical Industries Company-
known as PICL-
when it was recovered by Connell from Beltech.
Those transactions took place prior to the purchase by the Western Australian Government. The answer I received was:
The values of which the NCSC is presently aware are: September 1986-Mr Connell purchased half share in PICL from Dempster for $105,000.

In July 1987 there was the sale to Beltech of this half share, which has been denied by Connell, but the books of accounts show a valuation of roughly $21.5m for that half share in July 1987, just a year before the Western Australian Government purchase. In January 1988 L. R. Connell and Partners showed the valuation of the half share in its balance sheet at $75m. That was only a few months before the purchase by the Western Australian Government of that half share for $350m. That certainly raises more questions as to how this $350m figure was ever arrived at. The Western Australian Government's case was that a valuation was obtained to that effect. However, the Western Australian Government has never been prepared to make that valuation public, so I think we should take it with a grain of salt. The question still remains: How was that valuation arrived at? Supplementary answers that I have received provide the clue. The NCSC provided me with some clue in the first answers I received.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked about the purchase from Rothwells of the non-performing loans by Dalleagles, which is a Rothwells company. This is the response from the NCSC:

I asked:

In my first list of questions I asked, `How were these non-performing loans with a face value of $350m selected?' The NCSC had already indicated that probably their market value was only about 10 per cent of this face value. We had $350m being paid for debts that probably were worth only one-tenth of that. Naturally, I was interested in how those loans were collected. Now we have the answer that I have just read out. This raises matters of enormous significance for financial administration by governments in Australia. It shows that this sort of thing can occur. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Durack's contribution highlights the significance of the regulatory framework for companies and securities in Australia. It is that matter I wish to address. Following the Estimates committee hearings, the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation was set up by the Senate late last year. It presented its report, which has been debated in this place, earlier this year. That Committee was established to look at the proposals by the Government to radically change the regulatory framework for companies and securities, to move away from the cooperative arrangements that had served Australia so well over nearly the last decade in the form of a linchpin organisation, the National Companies and Securities Commission, supplemented by State corporate affairs commissions, and a ministerial council whereby the Federal and State and Northern Territory governments had a say in the administration and direction of the regulatory arrangements in Australia. That is now being swept away by this Government with the abolition of the NCSC, the ministerial council and all the cooperative arrangements, and their substitution by the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). That is a matter that has been debated at length both by this chamber and by the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation.

The Liberal and National parties were very strongly opposed to the Government's proposals to abolish the cooperative arrangements and substitute a new, bureaucratic, centralised framework based around an Australian Securities Commission. We have had the debate on that. Very regrettably, we, on this side of the chamber, did not get the support of the Democrats. Therefore, the legislation to establish the new arrangements has been passed by this Parliament.

In the course of debates in the Estimates Committee, the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation and this Senate, we raised time and again the importance of having adequate transitional arrangements from the existing situation to the new scheme proposed by the Government. In the debate on the corporations legislation package the Government said, in effect, as I understand it, that special transitional arrangements were neither envisaged nor necessary. That flew in the face of the very strong evidence that we received, as a Joint Select Committee, from a wide range of people in the business community and the companies and securities industry.
The report that the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation brought into this Senate stated, in chapter 2:

The Committee was told that the transition from the Co-operative scheme to the new scheme would, in addition to being constitutionally uncertain, be difficult and of unknown cost. Uncertainty as to transitional provisions have been claimed to have already caused a great deal of uncertainty in State CAC's, leading to a loss of capable and professionally qualified officers, according to submissions by State CAC's.
The Law Council of Australia also stressed the need for adequate transitional provisions. The Joint Select Committee report quoted the following words from the Law Council's submission:

Transitional provisions are designed to safeguard existing legal rights and obligations. It is therefore essential that these provisions work effectively. Past experience has shown that, to achieve this, it is necessary for provisions of this kind to be subjected to public scrutiny before passage. However, the great bulk of the transitional provisions have not yet been formulated.
The Joint Select Committee noted in paragraph 2.11 of its report:

The Committee notes that in a letter dated 29 April 1988 the Attorney-General has notified State Ministers that he will not proclaim certain of the legislation in the Bills package until a case determining the Constitutional validity of the new scheme has been determined by the High Court.
The Joint Select Committee went on to say:

. . . that, as a part of its response to this Committee's Report, the Government should provide the Parliament with an outline of what transitional provisions are proposed to allow a proper and orderly change from the co-operative Scheme to the new scheme.

That was a specific recommendation. The Government has refused to take up that recommendation. The reasons for it not doing so were explained very inadequately in the debate on the corporations legislation package. Since that debate concluded I, Senator Durack and others of our colleagues have continued to receive expressions of concern from the business community about the transitional arrangements to be applied. Yet, the situation seems to remain in a state of glorious uncertainty.
On coming into the chamber this morning I found on my desk the second reading speech on the Co-operative Scheme Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. The speech states:
As the Attorney-General indicated in the second reading speech when introducing the Bill into the House of Representatives-
this must have been yet another of those Bills which have been guillotined-

. . . the introduction of this Bill in no way diminishes the Government's commitment to the early implementation of the Commonwealth's Corporations legislation. That legislation has now been passed by both Houses of this Parliament and incorporates a number of amendments recommended by the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation.
I interpose to say it certainly does not incorporate the recommendations of the Committee in relation to transitional arrangements. The second reading speech goes on to say:
The Government will be proceeding to set up the machinery necessary for proper implementation of the national scheme as soon as possible.

In other words, there is no machinery yet in respect of implementation. If that is not what that statement means, it is a very badly drafted sentence indeed. The second reading speech goes on as follows:

In the meantime, the Government has indicated its commitment to maintain the existing scheme of regulation, including provisions for the protection of investors, pending the commencement of the national legislation.

That raises an enormous number of questions. It indicates nothing more than that none of the concerns that were expressed on this side of the chamber in the earlier debates-those concerns were reflected as well in the minority report of the Joint Select Committee in which all the coalition members of the Committee argued very strongly against the Government's proposals; and the whole Committee unanimously argued for transitional arrangements-appears to have been taken into account.

This is a matter of which the Minister for Justice should be aware. I say to him that there is a considerable degree of uncertainty and concern out in the community at a time when the last thing we want in this country is a denting of investor confidence. For heaven's sake, we are getting enough of that now as a result of the incredible economic policy performance of this Government. The economy is being bashed around the ears; the business community is being bashed around the ears and now, through administrative incompetence, it is about to be bashed around the ears again. I point out to the Minister that this is a matter of very grave concern not only to the coalition, but also to the players involved in this whole area, that is, participants and members of the companies and securities industry.

I request from the Minister an explanation, not just for coalition members of parliament but, more importantly, for the community, whose interests are vitally affected, as to what transitional arrangements are proposed; what will be the timing of the move from the NCSC to the ASC; what mechanics will be used in terms of almost certain High Court challenges to the legislation; how will the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) handle this matter when he says that certain elements of the legislative package will not be proclaimed until the High Court validity has been tested; and which certain elements will they compromise. In other words, there is an enormous number of unanswered questions that demand an answer. I hope that in this debate, brief though it is-and I appreciate the time constraints-we can at least start to get some of the answers to those questions and that we will get the rest of the answers very quick smart indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that many of these points were raised in the debate on the corporations legislation as it was passed through this chamber. TALK.START.PARA: —The mighty Clarence River in northern New South Wales runs very close to a small Aboriginal hamlet known as Baryulgil. Baryulgil is built on an asbestos mine and what has occurred there is quite disgraceful. Some of the matters are sub judice and I will be very careful about what I raise and what I do not raise during this discussion. It is worth reminding honourable senators that Woodsreef operated its mine at Baryulgil, the deposit of chrysotile having been discovered in 1918. The mining ceased in 1979. The tailings from the mine were used to fill in a couple of areas around the village. In an area known as Baryulgil Square the Aboriginal community built its houses on top of the tailings from the asbestos mine. The Government of New South Wales established the Baryulgil Primary School close by. It is built on tailings from the asbestos mine. The site contains a tonne of asbestos fibre.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently a handful of gravel from Baryulgil Square was sent to Western Australia coded. It was assessed in the laboratory of the Department of Occupational Health, Safety and Welfare as containing 10 per cent chrysotile, or white asbestos. That analysis was done in March 1989. A number of families with quite well known Aboriginal names-the Mundine family, for example- live in large numbers in Baryulgil. Most Aboriginals up there smoke. They were exposed to asbestos. It will not surprise honourable senators to know that the mortality was very high, that there were very few Aboriginals there who were more than 50 years old, that the rate of lung disease was high, and that the community suffered from the effects of exposure to asbestos fibre and, of course, from the effects of smoking-they exacerbate each other. The community there built shacks or houses on the area that became known as Baryulgil Square, which was eventually granted by the New South Wales Government to the then appropriate Aboriginal land body.

Soon after I became Minister for Aboriginal Affairs one of the first things I did, at the instigation of my Department, was to travel to Baryulgil and to make a ministerial decision that we would relocate that Aboriginal community away from the Square. Faced with the evidence that the community was living on top of asbestos fibre and the tailings from an asbestos mine, what other decision could be taken? The Department of Aboriginal Affairs-a very good department-constructed a village three kilometres away known as Malabugilmah. Many honourable senators collect trophies and the one of which I am proudest is a photo in my office of the tree under which we negotiated with the Aboriginal community the agreement which led to the establishment of Malabugilmah village.

The situation does not end there. From the asbestos-containing tailings on Baryulgil Square the run-off in heavy rain flows into Oakey Creek; from Oakey Creek the water runs into Joseph Creek and from Joseph Creek it runs into the Clarence River. About 50 metres down from the confluence of Joseph Creek and the Clarence River the water supply from the new Malabugilmah River is drawn. So one can presume that the water that is going to this Aboriginal community is rich in whatever comes from those tailings. I imagine that it contains some asbestos.

It took some time to get events under way. I started negotiations with the Government of New South Wales about the local school, because it was apparent that the schoolyard too was built on asbestos tailings. The then Minister in New South Wales, the late Paul Landa, and I corresponded. The school has not been moved, but some remedial work was done to the site. So great was the remaining problem of what was the proper course to be taken for the people who had lived their lives on Baryulgil Square, that in the mid-1980s-the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs says 1984, but I think it has to be 1983-the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Clyde Holding, gave a reference to the Committee to examine the effects of asbestos mining on the Baryulgil community. The House of Representatives Committee brought down its report to the Parliament in October 1984.

Honourable senators will be interested to know that that House of Representatives Committee was chaired by Mr G. L. Hand, MP, the person who is now the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and who is responsible for doing something about the matters which have been revealed. The report on the effects of asbestos mining lays out the history of the Woodsreef mine, the history of James Hardie, the company that ran the mine, making the point that it was in a very difficult position in relation to this investigation because of certain matters which are sub judice. The report sets out the history of housing at Baryulgil Square and the history of the development of Malabugilmah village. I interpolate here to say that there has been a failure to bulldoze what housing was built on the Square. The result is that as people moved from Baryulgil Square to Malabugilmah, other people moved into the housing that was left on the Square. So there are still Aboriginal families living on top of the tailings of the asbestos mine. My view is that we should find alternative housing and then get in there with a bulldozer and get rid of all the housing on the Square. Little children are still being brought up on top of the Baryulgil Square tailings from the Woodsreef asbestos mine, from chrysotile mining.

I have risen to make the point that this House of Representatives Committee made a number of recommendations in October 1984 and, to be fair, a number of those recommendations relate to action that is required by the New South Wales Government, but there are actions which are required to be taken by the Commonwealth. Mr Hand, who conducted the inquiry as Chairman, is now the Minister. At the very least there should have been pressure on New South Wales from the moment the report was brought down. Until one year ago the Government of New South Wales and this Government were of the same persuasion, so there should have been good communication. I have to say that there has been almost no action. There have been reports, there have been many meetings, there have been many pieces of paper going backwards and forwards and promises have been made, but I want outcomes. I want actions. I want to be able to look and say, `The children in the school at that village are no longer in any danger of asbestos exposure'-and I tell honourable senators that they are still in danger. As Minister I was very worried when I went there on my first visit. The school is too close to the tailings. Every time the breeze blows it blows asbestos into the playground. The playground itself had asbestos outcroppings. I do not believe that has been fixed, although I understand that the New South Wales Government has looked at remedial action. There might have to be a complete resurfacing of the school grounds. We want action and results so that no Aboriginal people continue to live on top of the asbestos tailings. That has not occurred.

Last night I saw a delegation from the community and it assured me that there are still significant numbers of people living on Baryulgil Square. How can that be? Mr Hand is the Minister who, as a backbencher, produced this report, so how can it be that he has taken no effective action? We know that the Malabugilmah village itself, the model village that was created, is having its own problems. Apparently there is some soil subsidence. Many of the houses have quite serious cracks. One of them has had the ceiling fall in because the walls have moved. What is being done to keep that housing in good shape? Recommendation 1 of the House of Representatives Committee states:
That the Attorneys-General of the Commonwealth and New South Wales consider ways and means whereby the technical difficulties presented by Aboriginality in seeking compensation may be removed.
What has happened since that recommendation in October 1984? Has the problem been fixed? Has any action occurred? Recommendation 2 states:

That the Commonwealth establish an Aboriginal Medical Service based in Grafton to cater for general health needs of the local Aboriginal communities and having expertise in the diagnosis and management of asbestos-related diseases.
Has it happened? Is it there? Recommendation 5 states:

That the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs continue to use every effort to persuade the residents of Baryulgil Square to move to another site removed from any risk to health from the Baryulgil mine site.
That has not happened, and it was a Commonwealth responsibility. Recommendation 6 states:
That the Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal Affairs recommend to the New South Wales Government that they institute a vigorous program to decontaminate Baryulgil Square as far as possible.
I am assured by the residents that that has not happened. Recommendation 7 states:

That the Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal Affairs request the New South Wales Government to direct the State Pollution Control Commission to continue to monitor the health risks from asbestos tailings at Baryulgil Square and to take whatever remedial measures may become necessary.

I do not know whether that has happened. There are other recommendations, one of which concerns the possible closure of the school and what would need to be done should that be necessary. The problem is that we can see no evidence of outcomes yet. I am aware that two Bills are in the Parliament of New South Wales at this moment-the Dust Diseases Tribunal Bill and the Workers' Compensation (Dust Diseases) Amendment Bill-which relate to action by that State to overcome some of the problems which the situation at Baryulgil has revealed. I hope that the Greiner Government in New South Wales will enact these pieces of legislation speedily. I ask honourable senators to be aware that we have at this little hamlet in New South Wales a disgrace, a preventable health problem, a problem where all we have to do is remove the people from exposure to asbestos. We have a report that tells us some of the ways in which to do it. The Committee which made the report was chaired by the person who is now the Minister, but nothing has happened. It is quite disgraceful and it is an indictment of this Government that the recommendations have not yet been implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was sitting in the chamber waiting to participate in the health part of the debate this morning, but clearly the matter which is before us now is really in the health area and it nicely bridges those two aspects of Aboriginal affairs and health. If there is one thing that we have learnt about the desirability of health services, it is that if we can prevent people from becoming ill, not only are those people much better off but the community at large is much better off because it faces a much lower cost. I extend Senator Peter Baume's remarks and point out that this has a long history. It is well known in medical literature that asbestos is an extremely dangerous substance.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, I did not intend to participate in this debate but, from memory, the first workers compensation case in the world which was successfully fought was in the United States of America in 1906. Of course, that was for chronic pneumoconiosis, the constrictive lung disease consequent upon the inhalation of very heavy fibre concentrations. In those early years most of the people who were exposed to asbestos died quite early from chronic lung disease, short of getting cancer. I believe that it was not until about 1918 that that was recognised and the concentrations of asbestos fibre to which people were exposed were sufficiently reduced so that people in that industry survived long enough for cancers to start to appear. I think the record shows that the Johns Manville Corporation knew by 1935 that asbestos was related to mesothelioma and lung cancer. Certainly by the 1950s there was a general and universal acceptance that that was the case.

Against that background I was absolutely shocked several days ago when people from Baryulgil came to see me and told me that an analysis done only within recent weeks indicated that the concentration of asbestos in the square in Baryulgil was still 10 per cent. That is an area where people are living; it is an area where children are playing; and that indicates a very high level of exposure. Senator Baume read into the record this morning the recommendations in the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. Against that, I can only say that the actions that this Government has taken to address that situation in a preventative sense are simply totally inadequate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we pass these appropriations I want to bring to the attention of this chamber the very real concerns that were expressed about numerous aspects of the operations and the administration of both the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission by all members of Estimates Committee E-and I stress the word `all'-who participated in that Committee's debate and considerations. As these Estimates committee reports tend to get buried I just want to put to this chamber some of the main points that were raised by Estimates Committee E in its considerations, because I think they are important points that often are not as widely recognised as should be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, as distinct from the Aboriginal Development Commission, I draw the attention of this chamber to the concern that was expressed by members of all parties to the question of performance indicators, which are integral to the success of program budgeting and the financial management improvement program, which has been an important part of the improvement of financial and other management in Government departments over recent years. The Department itself acknowledged that it is having difficulties in this area. The explanatory notes that we received gave several reasons for this, in particular the broad policy objective of self-determination for Aboriginal and Torres Strait islanders and the community-based nature of many departmental programs. The Committee certainly recognised that problems with the development of performance indicators are not unique to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs; it is a problem that bedevils quite a few departments. However, we were concerned, as an Estimates committee, that so little progress had been made in this area by the Department, particularly in the light of the review by the Audit Office, at the request of the Government, following matters that were raised in the Estimates Committee and in other areas late in 1988. They culminated in a special audit report by the Audit Office of the Department and that report was very highly critical of many of the operations of the Department. I will come to that a little later.
The Estimates Committee endorsed the comment of the Audit Office in its special report, which said:

The aims and objectives of some projects were defined too broadly for assessment. Statistics which would be required to enable an objective assessment to be made were not provided and performance measures used in the assessment of some projects needed to be reviewed.

The Committee said in its report that it recognised that the Department was seeking to remedy these problems and that it looked forward to seeing the results of its efforts at the Committee's next hearings. I am not suggesting that we need any additional response from the Department or from the Minister on that, but it is a matter that this chamber ought to be aware of.

Estimates Committee E was also concerned about the public awareness program being conducted by the Department. It is a program to address the question of the public perception of Aboriginal people in Australia. There was no dispute about that objective. However, a matter of concern to us was that neither the consultant nor the research officer for whom provision had been made to assist in this program had been appointed at this late stage in the 1988-89 financial year, despite the fact that a very significant financial commitment has been made for that purpose. The Committee was also questioning of whether consultants hired at this late stage in the financial year could make any worthwhile contribution to the expenditure of the unallocated proportion of the appropriation for that public awareness program. That unallocated portion is a significant figure-$733,000.

The Committee also drew attention to the extraordinarily high number of unacquitted grants made by the Department. In that context, I commend in particular Senator Crichton-Browne for having raised this issue in this chamber and for having brought it to our attention. The Audit Office report noted that a very significant number of grants by the Department remained unacquitted. According to the special audit report, no less than 783 grants totalling in excess of $67m remained unacquitted. All of those cases are in breach of the statutory requirement of the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976.

The Estimates Committee made it clear that the conditions for acquittal are not onerous. The recipient is required to produce within six months of the end of the financial year an externally audited financial management statement plus a certificate from the recipient's managing body that the recipient has complied with the grant conditions. Those conditions, as I say, are not onerous. The Committee also noted that a number of unacquitted grants had been significantly reduced in the past 12 months. But it did consider it a matter of continuing concern that grant conditions are not being met in such a large number of cases. I would like to hear from the Minister what actions may be being considered to improve that situation, which even the Prime Minister has recognised as being of an unacceptable standard.

That is a matter which the Minister may not wish to comment on in this context, but it is a point which I hope will be taken up by this Commission when producing witnesses at further hearings.

The Auditor-General's special report attracted a very strong response from the ADC. It is of concern that there has been such obvious friction between the Australian Audit Office and the Aboriginal Development Commission. Indeed, the Audit Office went so far as to describe the ADC's approach to the Audit as characterised by `a relative lack of cooperation not seen before from an official body'. That is a very strong statement indeed from a normally prudent Audit Office. I do not know whether the Minister wishes to comment on the matter, but I draw it to the attention of the Committee because of the strength of the Auditor-General's response.

The Estimates Committee, examining both the Audit Office and the ADC on this matter, did agree that, on the evidence available to it, the ADC's attitude to the special audit was a matter of concern and that there was real evidence that an uncooperative approach had been adopted by the ADC. We were also concerned, as was the Audit Office, about the ADC having retained private counsel to deal with the Audit Office. Indeed, the Attorney-General's Department has rejected some of the grounds on which the ADC sought to justify the counsel's appointment. In particular, we were concerned, as was the Audit Office and as was the Attorney-General's Department, at the retention by the ADC of Mr Michael Adams, QC, at a cost of some $125,000 just to assist the ADC in its dealings with the Audit Office in relation to the special audit. I might point out that Mr Adams is a Queen's Counsel whose practice is principally in the area of criminal law, not in the interpretation of the statutory powers of Commonwealth authorities, which was essentially the subject of the Audit Office's investigation. The Attorney-General's Department, the Audit Office and the Committee were very concerned about the justification put forward by the ADC for its action to retain Mr Michael Adams. Indeed, setting aside the nature of the individual, the whole question of whether private counsel ought to be retained by a statutory body or other government agency or department in matters such as this is an issue of considerable importance about which the Attorney-General's Department has expressed considerable concern.

The Attorney-General's Department wrote a letter dated 1 May. I do not have the letter in front of me, but in essence it stated that departments and agencies ought to rely initially on the advice of the Attorney-General's Department, rather than on advice from outside the scope of that well-established machinery. That view was endorsed by the Audit Office itself, which in its report to the Estimates Committee said:

The Audit Office notes that included in the amount of legal costs by the ADC is $125,000 for legal advice obtained during the audit from barristers and solicitors. In the Audit Office's view, this expenditure was unnecessary because the ADC could have obtained legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department. The Department has advised and informed the Audit Office that it would have charged the ADC only $3,500 for the legal advice that was given and that preparation of private legal advice also caused an unnecessary delay in the audit.

The Attorney-General's Department has said that the ADC wasted approximately $120,000 of taxpayers' money by going outside the available legal resources of the Commonwealth and employing a private counsel whose expertise does not lie in the area relating to the investigation. I believe that is a matter of considerable concern. Would the Minister care to make any comment on that at this stage-in particular, as to whether steps have been put in train to ensure that this type of thing does not occur again?

decisions taken contrary to published policy and guidelines without justification or reasons being given;

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister whether he would be prepared to take a preventive measure. Recommendation 6 of the 1984 report Effects of Asbestos Mining on the Baryulgil Community states:

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources to representations I received last week in the Riverina region of South Australia, particularly at Loxton, Berri and Renmark, concerning salinity levels in the River Murray. Can the Minister advise what action the Government is taking to address salinity problems in the Murray-Darling Basin-Australia's most important internal waterway? Is it the case that the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council is doing more at present than just commissioning further consultant studies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ministerial Council is doing more than commissioning further studies. The Council, which met some weeks ago, and which is composed of representatives of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and the Commonwealth, is a shining example of interstate and national cooperation to attack a major environmental and economic issue-the Murray-Darling Basin salinity problems-across State borders with an integrated plan to resolve the difficulties. At the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council meeting four weeks ago, the Council adopted a salinity and drainage strategy for the whole of the Murray-Darling Basin. This is the first time we have had such a strategy and we are now in the implementation phase of the strategy. The strategy provides a framework for joint government action and includes expenditure by the four governments over the next three years of $29.4m on several salt interception schemes, of which the Commonwealth will contribute $7.8m. The strategy will result in a reduction of 20 per cent in the average salinity of the River Murray as measured at Morgan in South Australia and will also provide the opportunity for protecting up to half a million hectares of high value land in the Basin area. The salinity and drainage strategy is one component of the broader natural resources management strategy being developed by the Council to address a range of natural resource problems facing the Basin. We expect there to be another Council meeting, somewhere along the River Murray but in South Australia, in October or November of this year. During that Council meeting the States and the Commonwealth are committed to resolving their differences and adopting a comprehensive natural resources management strategy for the whole of the Basin area. When that is done, it will be available for public comment and will then go into an implementation phase.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said, a jointly funded program of cost effective salt interception schemes to reduce River Murray salinity by up to 80 EC at Morgan in South Australia will occur. The initial program includes schemes at Woolpunda and Mallee Cliffs and the upgrading of existing schemes at Mildura, Merbein and Buronga. The Woolpunda scheme has been approved; construction has commenced and is expected to finish in 1991. An environmental impact statement for Mallee Cliffs is to be released soon for public comment. Work at Mildura, Merbein and Buronga will be completed in 1989-91. Changed operating procedures for Menindee Lakes and Lake Victoria to provide further reduction in salinity in the River Murray will occur. A number of other programs are cast broadly to involve the community in the Murray-Darling Basin area in working with the governments to implement salt reduction schemes. I must say to Senator Maguire that I am disappointed that, despite this good example of cross-political and State and Commonwealth cooperation on the Murray-Darling Basin, the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia-I think his name is Mr Olsen; he probably plays Jimmy Olsen to John Bannon's Superman-criticised the work of the Murray-Darling Basin, in a press release that he made some three weeks after the last Murray-Darling Basin meeting, as though these developments had not occurred.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL ENERGY AGENCY: REVIEW OF AUSTRALIA'S ENERGY POLICIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and refer him to the press release of the International Energy Agency's review of Australia's energy policies. Did the Minister note the comments made by the Agency on coal rail freight charges by the Queensland Government? What did the International Energy Agency's review of Australia's energy policies have to say on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Energy Agency (IEA) is a sub-agency of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and it recently completed a report which we regard as an audit of Australia's energy policies. It is a sort of peer group review to see how we line up with the rest of the developed world in terms of our energy policies. Before going into the detail of the honourable senator's question, I am pleased to say that we got a very positive report from the IEA. Senator Lewis and Senator Chaney might be interested to know that, for example, on a matter that they have been pursuing recently-excise-the IEA said of our excise regime on crude oil:

ANSWER.PARA: In the current circumstances, excise tax on crude oil production and other taxation arrangements seem appropriate to continue encouraging exploration and development of resources.
That is an external unsolicited comment, and I am pleased to see that it supports some of the comments I have made in answer to questions in this chamber.

Let me go to the question that has been asked of me. The OECD praised our deregulation steps in terms of liquefied petroleum gas and the domestic crude oil market. It noted that protection in other countries is adverse to Australia's energy trade. In all of this positive and, indeed, glowing commentary on our energy policies there was one sour note, which was a criticism of the States of New South Wales and Queensland. If one reads the real meaning of what is the polite and formal language of international public service, one can see that it is a quite substantial criticism of those two States.

Some weeks back I said to the Senate that Dr Brian Galligan, a political scientist from the Australian National University, in a paper entitled Queensland Railways and Export Coal, published in the Australian Journal of Public Administration in March 1987, estimated that the rail freight surcharge for Queensland coal in 1985-86 was $354m. That is a charge that goes to the mining operations, in addition to the cost of simply transporting the coal from mine to port. The IEA criticised New South Wales, which has a similar form of charge, and Queensland and said that that was an unfair charge against the development of those coal reserves. That lends support to the comments I have been making that this is a hidden tax which the State governments use to subsidise other activities. It enables those governments to pretend that they are low taxing States, which they are not. They do not open that tax for public scrutiny, and it is a tax on exports. At a time when we are trying to maximise our export trade, it is in that context a regressive tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the Treasurer's admission yesterday that monetary policy has been tightened. Does the Government concede it is locked into a further tightening of monetary policy, given the evidence of yesterday's national accounts that its current policy settings have failed to curb demand adequately?

—I do not concede that. The publication of yesterday's national accounts essentially describes activity in the economy between January and March. We are now in the month of May. The national accounts figures are of concern because they show a high level of imports and a high level of consumer spending, for a variety of reasons, but they also show an economy with a continuing high growth pattern through the March quarter. The honourable senator asked me whether these national accounts figures mean that monetary policy has inevitably to be further tightened. The answer to that question, I believe, is no, because there are a number of other economic indicators, published in late March and since then, which indicate-
—Is that the Treasurer's view, also?
—I am giving my view. If the honourable senator wants the Treasurer's view, he can write to him.

—Senator Watson asked me a serious question. I regard him as a serious person, and I am giving him a serious answer. I will continue to do so in spite of frivolous and, at times, cheap interjections from people like Senator Alston. I was making the point that the fact that the national accounts figures indicate very high growth in the economy between January and March does not necessarily indicate a further tightening in interest rates, as the question implied. There have been a number of other economic indicators since. For example, the fall of 11 per cent in housing finance commitments in March, making housing finance commitments 30 per cent below their peak in June 1988, suggests that overheating in the housing sector may come to an end as dwellings presently on order books are completed. There have been other indicators relating to consumption spending, such as private sector surveys, which have shown declines in consumer confidence, and lower expectations of business growth in the coming months. These indicators suggest a slowing of the economy-a slowing of demand-since the period covered by the national accounts figures. For those reasons, I answer as I did at the beginning-those implications do not follow.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Has the Minister taken into account in his answer the lagged effect of those surveys?

—I take it the honourable senator is referring to surveys concerning consumer confidence, business confidence and anticipation, and so on. Even if one takes into account what has been suggested is the lagged effect, I think the acceptance of those surveys operates pretty quickly. I think that would be confirmed by speaking to people in the business community and the housing sector. As far as anticipating a lag going beyond this quarter, I do not think that is likely.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Button. I do not know whether to describe him as a mega-Minister or a Minister for a mega-department. Finally, I refer to Mr Jones's statement:

QUESTION.PARA: The notion that 2 officers on a night shift provide an impenetrable barrier to the entry of illicit drugs is unrealistic.

If that is not a personal attack on the integrity and capability of officers of the Australian Customs Service, why are the training programs for Customs officers not upgraded to what the Minister regards as an acceptable level of performance-discounting, of course, his usual hyperbole about `impenetrable barriers'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know Mr Pickering personally. The first time I encountered him was when I heard him give an explanation of why New South Wales police officers shot a man in bed and shot the wrong man. It was an extraordinary explanation from a police Minister. The second time I heard of him was when he was complaining, in an attempt to boost his own image, about narcotics, when he was trying to divert blame for anything that occurred to the Australian Customs Service. That is the source of the comments which are the substance of the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: In its attempts to deal with the illicit narcotics trade, the Australian Customs Service has created contraband enforcement teams in the larger Australian ports. Those teams are in keeping with the ACS corporate plan to achieve more effective control through the use of risk management techniques. That is to say, instead of trying to man the Australian seaboard with a wall-to-wall collection of Customs officers, special units have been formed to deal with contraband, particularly in relation to narcotics. These teams are small, flexible and mobile, and analyse intelligence and information to identify targets representing high risk areas. They operate in all major ports and airports and can be redeployed rapidly, including to remote areas, as risks are identified. One element of the proposed restructuring at Newcastle and Port Kembla is the removal of the midnight shift. The Australian Customs Service proposes to service the Newcastle and Port Kembla areas fully between 7 a.m. and 11 p.m., but high risk activities at any time of the day or night will be handled by the contraband enforcement teams. There will be no reduction in staff at Port Kembla as a result of the formation of the contraband enforcement teams.

Mr Pickering, of course, as I suggested earlier, has been waging an active media campaign over recent months, trying to present himself as a hero in the narcotics fight and criticising the Australian Customs Service in the course of that process. Over the last 12 months the ACS has made many significant drug interceptions: in March 1989, January 1989, and the largest of all, I think, in June 1988. This month the contraband enforcement teams have aided the Australian Federal Police in the interception of large hauls of heroin in Sydney.

Whether the number of Customs successes in these activities is indicative of the amount of drugs coming into Australia is a question which I cannot answer. However, I can answer the allegations by Mr Pickering that there has been a reduction in barrier control staffing numbers. The 1987-88 ACS annual report suggests a slight reduction in that specific area, but that has to be seen in context. In round figures, there are 1,750 Customs officers performing barrier control and passenger processing functions. These are the front line officers. They are supported by 1,250 officers working in other Customs areas of direct relevance to enforcement-namely, investigations, coastwatch and import and export control. That amounts to approximately 60 per cent of total Australian Customs Service resources, excluding computer systems personnel and so on. The allegations by Mr Pickering, on which I believe the honourable senator's question is based, really are not valid.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNION OF SOVIET SOCIALIST REPUBLICS: ARMS REDUCTIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to various media articles about the most recent offer of arms reduction in Europe by the Soviet Union. Will the Minister support such initiatives and encourage the United States of America and its European allies to respond positively? Further will the Minister also encourage such a process in the Pacific, Northern Pacific and Asia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government has very much welcomed the strong and balanced improvement in East-West relations generally in recent years and the unprecedented opportunities that have emerged from this to decisively reduce military competition and to build in its place a constructive and cooperative set of relationships. We have been among the foremost of those who have recognised the enormous potential for positive change in the Soviet Union's program of internal reform and the supportive new thinking going with it on foreign and defence policy. We have taken the view that assessment of these changes should be based on deeds rather than words. Equally, the Government has long articulated the view that the West should take full advantage of the opportunities emerging from the process of change in the USSR.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result we have given full recognition to Soviet deeds, particularly to unilateral reductions in conventional forces that were announced by President Gorbachev last December. We consider the negotiations on conventional armed forces in Europe to be of central importance as they go to the heart of the whole postwar East-West conflict. The Government has been encouraged by the closeness of the opening of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) and Warsaw Pact positions in March this year even though the Pact position was more generally stated than that of NATO. The more detailed Warsaw Pact proposal that has been revealed this week confirms a very promising convergence of negotiating positions, particularly on tanks and armoured personnel carriers, two of the categories of special concern to NATO.

The latest Soviet proposal is quite complex but can be summarised in three sentences. Firstly, it has matched NATO reduction targets on tanks and armoured personnel carriers and has come close on artillery. Secondly, it proposes, in addition, radical reductions in troop numbers, combat aircraft and helicopters, whereas NATO has not proposed specific cuts in these categories. Thirdly, it has responded with counter-proposals on the proportion of total forces that can come from one country and the proportion of total forces that can be stationed in foreign countries. In the Australian Government's view the large and broad cuts that the USSR is now prepared to contemplate in its conventional posture in eastern Europe and European USSR is perhaps the most decisive indication that we have received to date that the new thinking is taking a firm root in the Soviet Union. We do not understate the difficulties remaining and the long course of negotiations that obviously still lie ahead.

Finally, as to the implications of all this for the Asia-Pacific region, we obviously attach importance to preserving and enhancing the security environment in this region. It is very different from and in many ways even more complicated than Europe from the standpoint of pursuing arms control arrangements. Security here has been enhanced by the varying degrees of progress that have been made towards the peaceful resolution of regional conflicts and points of tension-Afghanistan, Cambodia and the Korean Peninsula. Nearly two years ago this Government advocated greater transparency on force levels and doctrines in the North Pacific as well as United States-USSR military dialogue on security perceptions and concerns in this area. We will continue to advance proposals and suggestions of this kind if they are likely to prove helpful.
