DEBATE.TITLE: HORTICULTURAL LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989HORTICULTURAL LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989HORTICULTURAL EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a package of Bills dealing with the horticultural industry at a time when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has left this country to visit the Soviet Union to examine the art and architecture of the First Empire and at a time when the Reserve Bank of Australia has signalled that it is tightening monetary policy. It is a time when the Government is likely to be forced to tighten monetary policy further and a time when home mortgage interest rates are reaching a record level of 16.5 per cent and will possibly go to 17 per cent. As Mr Geoff Kitney in the Australian Financial Review of today said in summing up the national accounts figures which were released:

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, the national accounts figures were virtually a mirror image of the economic picture the Government has been attempting to draw. All the rises are where the falls should be and the falls are where the rises should be.

During the debate in this chamber in the last couple of days, the Government has been endeavouring to present to the people of Australia the complete reverse of the state of this economy as revealed by yesterday's national accounts figures. Meanwhile the Senate presses on trying to deal with legislation while the economy collapses in ruins around us.

The debate on the Horticultural Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, the Horticultural Levy Amendment Bill 1989 and the Horticultural Export Charge Amendment Bill 1989 gives me the opportunity to demonstrate that free enterprise is alive and flourishing despite the Hawke Government, a government that has created a dangerously overheated economy, an economy bleeding from the jugular vein. It is so overheated that, as I said, the Government is tightening monetary policy further and forcing interest rates even higher while the Treasurer slips away overseas to look at some lovely art and architecture in Leningrad. Those interest rises will hurt the entrepreneurs in the horticultural industry because they need to borrow funds to further expand, especially to expand their export opportunities.

The horticultural industry is essentially a free enterprise industry which comprises largely many small business people. It has the capacity to be a major export earner for this country from a relatively nominal capital base. Between 1986 and 1988 the export of grapes has grown from $16m to $38m. The export of fruit and nuts has grown from $128m to $154m. The export of plant seeds, flowers and bulbs, and live plants, has grown by an additional $2m. The export of cut flowers has grown from $5.5m to nearly $11.5m-over double. The total value of horticultural products exported from Australia has gone from $199m to $262m in two years. That is a substantial growth of which this country can be proud. But the potential for growth in this industry is absolutely enormous, and we should be doing more to assist this industry to become the major export earner that it could be.

The Government believes that this package of Bills will provide an incentive to those organisations which remain outside the embrace of the Australian Horticultural Corporation which was established in 1987 to join that Corporation. In fact, only the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation and the citrus industries were the original participants. Other horticultural industries fought shy of joining, despite financial incentives from the Government in the form of dollar for dollar funding to those industries joining the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. Some industries which might have joined recognised that the legislation made it uneconomical or impossible for them to join because of the way the levies and charges are paid. Others were wary of the bureaucratic constraints they could be exposed to. Their wariness was justified. The cost of collecting an estimated $600,000 in citrus levies per annum is about $122,000. This legislation proposes changes that will allow State bodies to collect the levies for the Commonwealth and that cost is estimated to be about $5,000 or, in the worst case, up to $20,000. The levy is to be increased from 2 per cent to a maximum rate of 5 per cent. With inflation running at somewhere between 8 and 10 per cent under the Hawke Government the trend is to impose the maximum levy to avoid the changes and amending legislation that would otherwise be necessary to keep up with inflation.

The nursery industry has already reached agreement with pot manufacturers to have the levy collected on the pots at the time of purchase, and these Bills will permit this. The Opposition applauds this as a sensible move. Other industries may prefer to pay their levy when they buy the trays they pack their fruit on. The horticultural industry now has the flexibility to allow economical collection of the levy to suit the producer, and levy collection costs should no longer be a barrier to organisations joining the corporations. The fact that more organisations have not displayed an interest in joining the corporations raises concerns about whether the levy difficulties were the sole barrier.

The growth of exports between 1986 and 1988 suggests that private enterprise flourishes best without bureaucratic oversight or constraints. I have previously drawn to the attention of this chamber and the Minister the bureaucratic difficulties experienced by horticulturalists in export inspection charges. That experience would be enough to keep many organisations away from any avoidable contact this bureaucracy. The Government should look to its bureaucratic practices and to its Business Regulation Review Unit, which we referred to during Question Time.

As I said before, next week the Government is to come up with a so-called micro-economic reform package. We can predict today what it will be. It will do away with the Industries Assistance Commission. It will do away with the Business Regulation Review Unit. It will combine them in a so-called Industry Reform Commission, which is like reorganising the chairs on the Titanic. Instead of addressing micro-economic reform measures, which the Government should be doing, it is reorganising the organisations which report to the Government about micro-economic reform. The Government should look to its bureaucratic practices for the reasons why in this industry organisations are staying away from these corporations. The Opposition does not oppose the legislation, but has reservations about the effectiveness of the corporations and the low number of organisations joining them. The corporations and their effectiveness will be reviewed as soon as we get into office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I express support for this package of horticultural legislation, the Democrats having supported the initial establishment of the horticultural corporations. I note that this package means that the nursery industry becomes the third product group to join the horticultural corporations after the apple and pear industry and the citrus industry, which came in when the corporations were formed.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to make a couple of comments specifically arising out of a concern which the Nursery Industry Association of Australia has conveyed to us. First, though, I acknowledge, as does the Nursery Industry Association, that it has had extensive participation in the development of this package of legislation. It has been closely involved in drafting the legislation and it supports its enactment. However, the Association's concern is that it believed that some funds would be made available for its use during the 1989-90 year while the levy funds established by this legislation were accumulating. The Association conveyed to me that it has now been made aware of a call for applications for funding. The industry is in the process of preparing a list of industry research priorities, having conducted an Australia-wide consultation. It is therefore not in a position during the first year to apply for specific project funding since its priorities are still in the process of being established. It had thought that funding would be available on a general basis in the first year of establishment. It is concerned about what it calls an oversight, and is disappointed in view of the fact that it has had extensive involvement in the development of the legislation.

It indicates, at least at this point, a breakdown in what appear to have been very useful and valuable communications and consultations. I simply put on record the Nursery Industry Association's concern and its disappointment and call on the Government to look again at what appears to be a call for funding for specific projects. Perhaps the Government will allow funding on a more general basis in the interim year while the levy funds established by the legislation are put in place.

I endorse those remarks of Senator Lewis which refer to the tremendous potential in the horticultural industry for development of exports to the benefit of our national economy. We have often made that point in debates relevant to this industry. I simply reiterate another point that we have made quite readily; that is, that within the horticulture industry perhaps the most exciting avenue open to us in terms of export development and growth is in clean horticultural products. The Northern Hemisphere, in particular, is crying out for chemical-free food produce. The concerns of consumers around the world about their health and the environmental degradation of which chemicals use is a part are now very prominent. Indeed, if Australia does not back moves which are very strongly afoot in this country to develop clean and sustainable agriculture, we will miss out on a very important export opportunity, especially since our New Zealand neighbours are very well advanced in the establishment of standards and in the assistance and support provided to industry for the export of clean food products. The demand is there. The Federal Government must do more than it has done so far.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has made a commitment and some action has been taken. At the Australia-New Zealand Ecological Agriculture Conference in Brisbane in February, at which I was present, the Minister said that the Government recognised this market opportunity and urged the industry to take up the opportunities. The Australian Democrats say that the Government must support industry in doing this and, at the very least, some of the Government support for research and development of the industry which currently goes to conventional and in some cases very heavy chemically involved practices should be diverted to those areas which are currently trying to develop without very much government or established support. The Democrats support this legislation and look forward to further encouraging developments in the horticultural industry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a Bill for an Act to amend the Air Navigation Act 1920. This is a simple Bill because it seeks to alter section 13 of the Air Navigation Act of 1920 by inserting the word `vary' after `may'. The Senate would be aware that there are reciprocal agreements in relation to traffic rights for international airlines operating into and out of Australia. Under the Air Navigation Act the only power that the Government has with one of its signatories to traffic rights within Australia is to cancel the licence. There is no flexibility in the arrangements that exist at present to allow the Minister to do anything other than that. If there is a dispute or disagreement with the airlines of another country coming to Australia, there is no facility for them to be censured in any way other than the cancellation of their licence. That is a very extreme step and it may well make the problem worse. The amendment to section 13 by adding the word `vary' after `may' allows the Minister a range of options. It allows the Minister to vary the number of flights, the type of aircraft being used and, therefore, the capacity, and even the routing system that is applied to those aircraft coming into Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's amendment has become necessary because other countries have taken action in reaction to Australia's positions or actions in the past or things that Australia's national carrier, Qantas Airways Ltd, has done. The Opposition will support the amendment to the Air Navigation Amendment Bill because we see it as necessary. Consequential on the passing of this legislation, changes will be required to air navigation regulations 106b and 106c. Air navigation regulation 106b relates to timetables and 106c relates to the suspension and cancellation of approvals.

Since this Bill deals with international air travel I wish to take about three minutes of the Senate's time to touch on a few points about international aviation and its importance to this country. Our national economy is increasingly dependent on the profits from tourism. We have only one national carrier in the international field, that is, Qantas. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would be aware that Qantas is in quite a lot of trouble at present and a large part of that stems from Qantas's mismanagement. I have referred in previous speeches in this chamber to the absolutely inexcusable politicisation of the Board of Qantas. One-third of the members of the Board are political hacks. Their only attribute is the fact that they are loyal members of the Australian Labor Party. We simply cannot run a business as cut throat as an international airline, where we are up against some of the best businessmen in the world, with one-third of the Board of management composed of people who simply have no commercial experience or ability whatsoever. That is an enormous liability for Qantas to carry.

As a consequence, we are seeing Qantas's inability to compete successfully in the expanded market that is now available in Australia. We are seeing the exportation of jobs which should be done in Australia, such as the maintenance of aircraft. Qantas has contracted tens of millions of dollars of maintenance work to a whole range of overseas airlines, from United Airlines in America through to Aer Lingus Airlines, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and Air France in Europe, simply because of the short-sighted management practices of Qantas. It has not trained enough engineers and pilots. The Royal Australian Air Force has been denuded of over 300 pilots, a large number of whom have gone to Qantas. It is reasonable to criticise Qantas's management for not seeing that it has an essential interest in running its own training programs for pilots and engineers, without which the airline cannot survive. The airline is certainly large enough to do its own in-house training.

Another of Qantas's management problems is the way it has dithered about moving out of the Sydney maintenance area. As we all know, the Sydney airfield is now more or less fully expanded; there is simply not enough room to expand. Qantas is virtually doubling its airline fleet and it has a requirement for new overhaul facilities. Again, that has been apparent for years. I think it was in 1982 that I first put publicly the proposition that Qantas should move some of its maintenance facilities for the new aircraft coming in, such as the 767 fleet, to Brisbane, where there is plenty of land and, most importantly, labour is available. One of the great problems with Sydney is not only the shortage of land but also the difficulty of getting suitably qualified people to work there. Because of the very high cost of real estate and the huge distance that people have to travel if they are employed in Sydney, it is very difficult for any company in any field of activity to transfer people in from outside to work in the Sydney environment. There is no prospect of that easing in the future; it will just get worse.

I am reliably informed that, having dithered over this for nearly six or eight years, Qantas has now been directed by the Government, in another piece of pork barrelling, to create its new maintenance facilities in Melbourne. This present Labor Government imagines that there is some political advantage in seeing a Qantas facility developed there. It is the old story of looking after political interests instead of economic interests. In this case a national economic interest is being prostituted by people in this Government leaning on their mates on the Board of Qantas.

I have referred in previous speeches to the difficulty Qantas faces with its undercapitalisation and to numerous statements by the Chairman of Qantas, who is a very competent businessman, that the preferred debt to equity ratio of 70:30 simply cannot be maintained with the huge capital needs that the airline faces in the future. The only way the future of Qantas can be guaranteed is for the Government to accept the Liberal-National Party proposal and privatise it. The days are long past when this Government can go to the Australian taxpayer and raise the hundreds, if not billions, of dollars needed to shore up both Qantas and Australian Airlines.

One of the problems that this Government has manifested in relation to the whole of the airline industry is that it has seen the industry as a taxing base and has done nothing about the infrastructure and the maintenance of that infrastructure, which is so vital not only for our own airlines but also for overseas airlines coming in to the country. It is absolutely absurd for international airlines-and by definition that means that the crews have limited and sometimes no knowledge of local conditions-to operate into an airport such as the one at Cairns without the provision of terminal radar. Those are not even Third World standards. The climatic conditions in Cairns are often bad. It has a high rainfall and it is surrounded by hills and mountains which are in close proximity to the airfield. Yet this Government has fiddled and diddled around and done nothing for the six years it has been in office, and in that time Cairns has expanded into one of the busiest airports in Australia. In the next 12 months it will overtake the Gold Coast airport and probably move into fourth or fifth position in Australia in respect of traffic density.

We have heard all the arguments in this chamber about the inadequacy of Adelaide and Melbourne radar. Again, this Government has done nothing to support the infrastructure for the airways of the country. Although the radar system in Melbourne is a new system it is simply the wrong system for terminal radar. It is an en route radar. It is not a matter of tuning the software program, as various Labor Party Ministers have sought to convince the Australian community; it is a matter of throwing it out and buying something that is appropriate. Needless to say, the Government has gone ahead and bought the same sort of system for Adelaide and I believe that it proposes to install the same system in Perth.

The provision of the infrastructure required for safe operation just cannot be avoided. This is one of the obligations that this Government just has not picked up. It amuses me to hear Government speakers in this place and in the other place bleating about Australia's brilliant safety record in the air. They simply do not understand how safety in air operations is assured. They do not understand the fundamentals. They do not know how we got to the position of having safe operations in this country. More importantly, they do not understand the dramatic erosion in air safety that has taken place in the six years of this Government.

The incident we heard about on the news last night of an Australian Airlines Boeing 737 mistaking the Bruce Highway for the Mackay Airport in bad weather is proof of what I am saying. Nothing has been done to Mackay in the last six years, although it, along with Cairns and the Gold Coast, has expanded enormously with the increase in tourist traffic. Mackay is not an all-weather airport; like Cairns, it is subject to bad tropical low pressure systems.

There is not a word out of this Government about the need to address housekeeping issues that are fundamental to the maintenance of our safe air navigation record, which is now being very considerably eroded. I do not propose to take the time of the Senate any longer on this Bill, and on behalf of the Opposition I wish it a speedy passage.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President has received a letter from Senator Boswell proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of successive Territories Ministers to adequately fulfil their Ministerial responsibilities with respect to Christmas Island and the inadequacy of Senator Richardson's explanation as to why the government has accepted the recommendation of the assessor of Christmas Island mining proposals.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -For some time now I have been asking Senator Richardson questions about the validity of the assessment of future mining proposals for Christmas Island. During that time, I believe Senator Richardson has misled the Senate three if not four times. This is getting to a very serious stage. Even more serious is the fact that it belies the fact that a department is so contemptuous of ministerial authority that it is prepared to allow its Minister to mislead Parliament blatantly. I have given the Government every opportunity to acknowledge what the Opposition has been saying for two years, that is, that the external territories bureaucracy has been pursuing its own agenda for Christmas Island. I want Senator Richardson to acknowledge that his Department has been playing him off a break. So far he has apologised for only one point, which he has described as minor, although I acknowledge that he has frozen the signing of any contracts and has arranged a meeting to examine the claims of unsuccessful companies.

SPEECH.PARA: However, Senator Richardson has so far failed to acknowledge his other misleadings of Parliament. More importantly, by failing to do so he has failed to acknowledge, let alone appreciate, the full extent of maladministration in his Department. I am therefore bound to pursue this issue. To understand these issues properly we must look at some recent history. On one hand we have the Chinese-Malay workers led by Gordon Bennett, the Secretary of the Union of Christmas Island Workers, and on the other hand we have the Australian bureaucracy, which is trying to run Christmas Island from Canberra. In the last two years the struggle between these two parties has seen the sacking of the Christmas Island Assembly, a democratically elected body; the shutdown of the phosphate mining operations; and moves to depopulate the island by such means as massive rent increases and the discouraging and retarding of development. On 3 November 1987 the Government dismissed the new and democratically elected Christmas Island Assembly for being unwilling or unable to balance the budget of the Christmas Island Service Corporation (CISC). I seek leave to table the relevant minute.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assembly had projected a $2.6m deficit for 1987-88, which it tried to revise to a $41,000 surplus. This was following a $1.65m surplus for 1985-86 and a $336,000 deficit in 1986-87. Significantly, a minute to the new Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Holding, from his Department in December 1988 contradicted the Government's excuse for sacking the Assembly. Incredibly it says:

SPEECH.PARA: It would be unfair to blame the Assembly entirely for the financial malaise of the Christmas Island Services Corporation, and, indeed, they instigated a round of redundancies with UCIW support . . .

More significantly, this minute said that the Assembly `asked the Government for support and we provided them with accountancy support and management and a local government consultancy'. This totally contradicts the statement in the Government's media kit issued by Senator Richardson at the time of the Assembly's sacking which said that the Assembly did not seek the assistance of the Department in overcoming this problem. I have already tabled that minute. The minute also reveals that under Government control the projected CISC deficit for 1988-89 was revised from a deficit of $2.6m to a $41,000 surplus. Under the Government's control the deficit figure blew out to $7.245m. This is a shocking indictment on Senator Richardson and other external territory Ministers. In fact, one should ask why the Assembly got the chop for being on the verge of going broke when the record showed that they were far better financial managers than were Senator Richardson and his Department. It could be construed that the Assembly's sacking was nothing more than the means of silencing opposition to mine closure and to depopulation of the island, for it was only a week later, on 11 November 1987, that the Government announced a shut-down of mining-a black day for all Christmas Islanders. The Government cited industrial disputation by the Union of Christmas Island Workers as a major reason for the closure.

Mr John Brown, the then Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, on his visit to the island in early September 1987, told the Union of Christmas Island Workers to lift its bans or the mine would close. On 16 September he issued a press release indicating that if the bans were lifted, there would be work for 300 miners for a further 2 1/2 years. In fact, these bans were lifted after Mr Brown's visit to the island and before the Minister issued his press release. Yet the Government dis- honoured its promise and went ahead with the close-down of mining on 11 November 1987.

When the Hawke Government came to power in 1983 there were 3,000 people on Christmas Island. Now, only 1,000 remain. For two years the Opposition has warned successive Territories Ministers that the Territory bureaucracy was running its own policy on Christmas Island. However, despite this warning, the Government and its Ministers have invariably refused to listen. Mr Brown was manipulated by his Department because of his own lack of interest; Mr Punch was manipulated because of his naivety.

In March of this year the Federal Court handed down a decision on a challenge by Century Metals and Mining to have the decision on a successor operator reviewed. The challenge failed on legal grounds, but pointedly, the court said its decision did not reflect any view it had on the correctness of the assessment. Indeed, the court took the extraordinary step of finding that successive Ministers and their advisers were `not above criticism'. It found the whole decision-making process on a successor operation to have been, `essentially political'. It also found the assessment's characterisation as independent `a tactic redolent of Sir Humphrey Appleby'. Let me tell Senator Richardson that that is scathing criticism of his Department, not by the Opposition but by a Federal court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not recall being attacked in that decision.
—One would have thought that Mr Holding or Senator Richardson, if they did not heed the Opposition, might at least take notice of the Federal Court.
—Will you quote to me where I was attacked in that decision by the court?

—Incidentally, the minute this challenge failed, Senator Richardson's Department sent in the rent collectors and threatened to sue the islanders if they did not meet the back rents. What makes the Federal Court's criticism of Mr Punch even more damning is that, throughout his time as Minister, the Opposition had constantly told him where his Department had been misinforming him. A prime example of this was the appointment of Mr Yeomans, the liquidator of the Government's phosphate mining corporation, who was appointed to assess mining proposals. Prior to his appointment, the Opposition told Mr Punch that the assessment should be done by private consultants and it warned that there may be problems with Mr Yeomans's suitability. Significantly, the Federal Court found that, from the Department, Mr Yeomans had formed an unfavourable view of Mr Bennett and his union and that, contrary to his affidavit evidence, Mr Yeomans did criticise Century's involvement with the Union of Christmas Island Workers well before his assessment.

SPEECH.PARA: I now wish to examine the process leading up to Mr Yeomans's assessment. Following the shutdown of mining, several private groups expressed interest in continuing mining on a smaller scale. As a result of pressure, Mr Punch decided to conduct the so-called `independent' assessment of these proposals. There were three major contenders-Century Metals and Mining; Elders Resources; and a consortium headed by Mr J. G. Booth. Mr Yeomans's assessment recommended Elders Resources, a company that originally did not propose any islander equity participation and a minimum of islander worker participation. Not only were the worker participation and equity aspects of other mining submissions superior but also one was superior in terms of higher royalties to the Commonwealth and its commitment to the environment. Let me make it quite clear: I am not alleging any impropriety by Elders. However, the assessor, Mr Yeomans chose its proposal over two others, one of which, on current market prices would have offered 30 to 100 per cent more in royalties.

I now come to where Senator Richardson has misled the Senate three, if not four, times over this assessment of mining proposals. In March this year I asked on notice whether the assessor had recommended the proposals which best maximised returns to the Commonwealth in terms of both net payments and royalties. In answer, Senator Richardson said that the liquidator had indeed done so. He stood by this in answering a question without notice in the Senate on 3 May. The facts are that both Booth and Elders offered a net payment of $500,000 for the assets of the Phosphate Mining Christmas Island Corporation. However, on the question of royalties, Mr Yeomans's assessment itself acknowledged that the Booth proposal offered slightly higher royalty payments.

In the Senate on 5 May, when I challenged Senator Richardson on these answers, he insisted that Elders' proposal did maximise returns to the Commonwealth because it also offered rehabilitation to the value of $1 per tonne, and that this offset Booth's superiority on royalties. The Minister was relying on a departmental brief and I believe that this brief was wrong.

On 8 May I asked Senator Richardson how he could say this when the assessor had made no comparison on the basis of rehabilitation and Booth had in any case assumed an open-ended responsibility to rehabilitate all mined areas. On 9 May, Senator Richardson begrudgingly apologised and admitted that rehabilitation was indeed not relevant to the assessment and should not have been used in commenting on the original proposal. He even conceded that the Booth proposal might be a few hundred thousand dollars better in terms of royalties over 18 years. But this was a very selective apology and, indeed, the Minister went on to compound this misleading. This time he asserted that it was Elders' superiority in financial resources and other matters going to capacity to pay which offset Booth's edge on royalties.

There are grave problems with his latest explanation. Firstly, the assessor himself acknowledged that Booth's price estimates were conservative, and that Booth's proposal was still slightly superior to Elders on royalties. Elders were offering a fixed $1.70 per tonne royalty whereas Booth was offering a 5 per cent indexed rate. Secondly, and more importantly, Mr Yeomans's assessment compared Booth's proposal on royalties with the better, rather than the worst, of basically two Elders' options.

Elders was proposing two possible options with two possible variations. One option was for stockpile removal only, while the other involved utilisation of cleared areas as well as stockpiles. The amount of phosphate shipped again depended on whether it was upgraded by washing `B' grade phosphate into `A' grade. Elders' proposal thus stated that it was going to ship anything from 300,000 to 450,000 tonnes of product a year.

Obviously, the option and variation ultimately used would have a profound effect on the amount of royalty the Government could expect to receive. While Elders' proposal would have returned no more than $11.5m, this may have been as little as $7m, depending on the option it used-a difference of nearly $5m. How could the assessor justify an uneven and arbitrary comparison of Booth's proposal with the best Elders' contingency when there was no assurance what option Elders would pursue?

The Booth proposal, as acknowledged by the assessor, conservatively yielded $11.7m in royalties. Even in terms of the assessment, the Booth proposal could yield up to $5m more in royalties and, on current market prices, up to $7.5m better. What makes this look worse is that at the recent Senate Estimates hearing I asked the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories whether Mr Yeomans ever tried to get Elders to change its flat rate royalty offer in an effort to negotiate a selling price figure. In other words-did Mr Yeomans ever try to get Elders to change its royalties offer to make it more like Booth's offer, which was indexed to selling price? The answer I received was yes, this was tried seven times. A number of meetings were called to try to get a change to the Booth proposal, not once, but seven times.

The third problem with Senator Richardson's latest justification of Mr Yeomans's assessment is that it overlooked Booth's open-ended offer to rehabilitate all mined areas, based on a negotiated rehabilitation program. This made it superior to Elders' rehabilitation proposal, which was limited to $1 per tonne. In the likely event that the rehabilitation costs exceeded $1 per tonne, Booth's proposal guaranteed a high standard of rehabilitation. On top of this, Booth has also complied with Mr Punch's advice to the assessor about employment preference for Christmas Islanders.

Thus in three areas-royalties, environment, and equity and employment for islanders-Booth was superior. Yet the Minister has been insisting that the Elders' proposal maximised potential returns. He has also been insisting that, in recommending Elders, Mr Yeomans acted in accord with the advice of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that he could determine which proposal maximised returns to the Commonwealth, but could not be concerned with the viability of proposals, except where this might go to the capacity to pay. This is another aspect of Senator Richardson's repeated misleading. Every time he has claimed that Elders maximised returns to the Commonwealth, he has also claimed that the assessor acted in accord with the Attorney-General's advice.

I am at a loss. Surely, capacity to pay is a question of threshold rather than degree, otherwise every big company would win contracts on size rather than on capacity to perform the work or pay. The assessment itself acknowledged that the companies in the Booth consortium were experienced in mining and, viewed collectively, were companies of substance. Did not the Booth consortium therefore satisfy the capacity-to-pay criterion?

Senator Richardson will have to put down some type of statement; otherwise he will be judged as either complacent in his misleading of Parliament or incompetent and unable to run a department which administers territories. If he cannot explain his statements, he must investigate the reasons for the assessment's miscarriage, explain why he and his junior Ministers have allowed such a miscarriage to occur, and tell us what his Government will do to put its administration of external territories on a proper footing.

Over the last two years we have seen maladministration of Christmas Island. We have seen persecution of Christmas Islanders. We have seen jobs being shut out. We have seen their elected assemblies closed down. We have seen rents being hiked up beyond a capacity to pay-by 150 per cent on some occasions. We have seen everything done to depopulate those islands without care or concern for Christmas Islanders. If Senator Richardson wants to do this he should at least be open and honest by telling them that they have to get off the island. He should not keep using guerilla tactics against them. He should give them a chance to exist. It is their homeland. He would not allow a mining proposal to go to the Christmas Islanders because it contained islander equity and a proposal for the employment of 70 islanders. He gave it to another company that proposed to fly people in and out on a 14-day working shift, working 12 hours a day, and which did not propose to employ any islanders, or a minimum of islanders. Everything that the Minister's Department has done over the last two years has been to the detriment of Christmas Islanders. I now seek an explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell will get an explanation. Later on, depending upon time constraints, I will try to cover his continued allegations about my misleading of the Parliament. I have done this here before at some length.
—What? Misled the Parliament?
—I have explained it, Senator. The difficulty is that it does not matter how many times something is explained to Senator Boswell; it takes him a long time to understand explanations.
—What about credibility?

—When it comes to credibility on the environment, Senator Puplick's is nil. No doubt that is something we shall identify and get a little closer to in the coming couple of weeks. I return to the subject of Christmas Island. I begin by agreeing with some of the words of today's proposal. I would not want to be seen disagreeing with Senator Boswell all the time. I agree that successive territories Ministers have not fulfilled their responsibilities in regard to the operations of Christmas Island. That is a certainty.
—Hear, hear!
—When Senator Boswell hears their names he may not say `Hear, hear'. There is no question whatsoever that Christmas Island--
—It is the streaker's defence.

—God forbid that Senator Boswell would ever be a streaker! Looking at Christmas Island today I would have to acknowledge immediately that it is an island that has faced, and will continue to face, some serious difficulties. It is not the first isolated mining community that, after a mine has come to the end of its life, has faced those difficulties. It is 2,600 kilometres from the nearest major city. It has, admittedly, spectacular flora and fauna and some magnificent rainforest but its soils are poor and the rainfall is very slight. In a couple of recent years rainfall has been below average. It has no beaches. So its attractions to those outside, especially as the ore deposit is diminished and depleted, are very small indeed. Christmas Island began its life as a phosphate mine near the end of the last century-1887 is a date that comes to mind. From that time until the mid-1970s it operated as a colonial outpost. Marg Neale, a former resident of Christmas Island, wrote a book, which was launched by Mr Holding, in which she said:

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia at the time the political cry was `It's time for a change' and the public issues of the day revolved around racial equality, wage justice, conservation and environmental protection. These sentiments echoed resoundingly at the polls with the election of the Labor Government in 1972. Meanwhile, in this part of Australia, guest labour was still imported from Asia on $1.20 per day, no unions existed, and mining went on relatively unchecked in the unique rainforest and nesting habitats of many rare and endangered species.
That is a pretty damning indictment of previous conservative governments. But they were not the only conservative governments since the--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not interested in that; I am interested in 1989.
— Senator Boswell, as a member of the National Party, is basically interested in the 1950s but I will take him beyond that.
—Well, you have only a quarter of an hour.

—If I had a month I would not be able to explain anything to Senator Boswell. As I said, Senator Boswell is very slow on the uptake. Australia assumed sovereignty for Christmas Island in 1958. (Quorum formed) As I was saying before the quorum was called, since Australia resumed responsibility for the island in 1958, a succession of Ministers managed to ignore totally the plight of the islanders. If one looks at the list of those Ministers who ignored the plight of the Islanders, it is not a bad little list. Mr MacKellar, Mr Peacock, Mr Wilson, Mr Ellicott and Mr McVeigh all failed to come to grips with what was going on in Christmas Island. But I will at least give Mr Ellicott the credit for setting up an inquiry into what was happening on Christmas Island; at least he was concerned enough to do that. We had the Sweetland Commission of Inquiry into the Viability of the Christmas Island Phosphate Industry. The difficulty was that, having set up the inquiry, the Fraser Government chose to ignore its findings and implemented none of its recommendations. As usual, it was left to a Labor government to clean up the mess. Since we came into office, that is exactly what we have attempted to do on Christmas Island.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1984, the then Minister for Territories and Local Government, Mr Tom Uren, announced a package of measures to bring Christmas Island into line with mainland Australia. That meant normal social security and health benefits to Christmas Islanders; wage rates were to be determined applying the same principles as applied generally to Australian wage earners; the Government owned mining company, the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd, would shed many of its non-mining functions; local government would be introduced and municipal charges would apply.

It is interesting to note that those in the Opposition who continually preach the doctrine of user pays being the only way for us to go in the future always seem to balk when any user has to pay. While the Union of Christmas Island Workers was formed and became very active in only comparatively recent times, it got the Christmas Island workers' conditions way in front of those on the mainland and they were enjoying subsidies available to no-one on the mainland. The Government simply sought to rationalise that situation.

There has never been a policy of the Government to depopulate the island. But it must be remembered that to close a mine which has operated on the scale that this mine had-quite obviously, it was the major employer and the only possible major employer on the island-and replace it with an operation that will employ fewer people-this operation, from memory, will employ less than 100 people when it recommences-obviously is not the answer. One cannot sustain all of the Islanders on such a reduced operation. There is no great secret about that. Obviously, when the phosphate runs out, there will be problems for the island. To try to deny that is just nonsense.

The question that follows is: What do we do about it? It should be mentioned here that a lease for the resort casino site was signed last week while my colleague, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Holding, was visiting the island. The project is on schedule. It has a June-July this year commencement date so it will commence in the next few months, and we look forward confidently to the opening of the resort casino towards the end of next year. That casino will employ about 100 people during the construction phase. It will employ a couple of hundred people during its operating phase. The Minister for Employment and Education Services, Mr Duncan, has taken an active interest in the Christmas Islanders and their plight and is making sure that there are training programs available to ensure that they get the great bulk of those jobs. Again, that is the proper thing for this Government to do.

Currently about 10 organisations are interested in refurbishing the existing accommodation on the island and, hopefully, that will commence soon. In addition there will be associated resort activities which will employ more people, such as game fishing, scuba diving, and nature walks; and there will be more restaurants and shops, and so on. That is one of the options-not the only option-which the Government sees as being the right way to go for the future of Christmas Island.

Senator Boswell and I have one other thing in common-neither of us has been to Christmas Island. I do not pretend, therefore, to be an expert on it. Nonetheless, I have read quite a bit about the place in recent years, especially in recent weeks. I am sure that Senator Boswell is aware, as I mentioned earlier, of the vast array of unique attractions in terms of the flora and fauna of the island and its rainforests. We would like to make sure that tourism exploits those features. Hopefully, that will play a large part in the island's economic future.

Recently I referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts and its reference to inquire into tourism in the Cocos and Christmas Islands. As well as those initiatives in the tourist field to make sure there is a future for Christmas Islanders, my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Kerin, has before him now a draft memorandum of understanding for the establishment of a commercial tuna fishing industry on Christmas Island. In addition, my Department is exploring other ventures in which we can involve ourselves on Christmas Island to make sure that there are even more local employment opportunities for Christmas Islanders. There are some problems on the question of fishing boundaries, which I am sure Senator Boswell will be aware of; nonetheless, we are proceeding down that track.

The Government has also, through its recent customs and excise legislation, extended forum nation status to Christmas Island as well as the Cocos Islands and Norfolk Island. This provides for a preference to the islands under which goods manufactured on the islands which meet a 50 per cent local labour and materials requirement will receive duty-free entry to the Australian mainland. This Government has taken a whole series of steps to undo the decades of neglect that the islands suffered under successive conservative administrations.

Last week the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Holding, visited Christmas Island. Fortunately, there were some developments which give us cause for renewed hope for the islands agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a word about the assessor's report.

—I will continue to ignore Senator Puplick. That has been pretty easy for the last couple of years. The Minister spoke to Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) personnel and the Union of Christmas Island Workers (UCIW). What comes through from the Minister's discussions is that debate on the island about its own future is well in advance of Senator Boswell's remarks today. Negotiations are proceeding on the island between the Union of Christmas Island Workers and the Elders consortium about the future of mining on the island. Those negotiations proceed amicably and are close to fulfilment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Assembly was not only the voice of the people; it was also very responsive to the environmental problems on the island. For example, the Assembly recommended the preservation of the forest habitat of the Christmas Island frigate bird. We have heard a lot about the Abbott's booby; what about the Christmas Island frigate bird? The Assembly took a strong stand against the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island in relation to the extension of mining to the shores of Smithson Bight and considered, in the land use survey of 1985, that the conservation habitats there were of international concern with their outstanding coastal scenery, landscapes and wildlife. As a result of the recommendations which were passed by the Assembly, mining of the terraces did not proceed. Whatever the future of Christmas Island, the fragility of the environment must be taken into account. I note that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, pointed out in his contribution that the Government is aware of that fragility. I applaud him for that. Until the mid-1970s, as Senator Richardson also pointed out, the island was regarded as just a source for cheap phosphate with an expendable Asian work force. However, in the mid-1970s, the price of phosphates had declined and at the same time the work force had unionised.
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, felt moved to write a small contribution for the dust jacket of Les Waters's book entitled The Union of Christmas Island Workers. The Prime Minister said:

This is the story of how a small union in a remote and little known Australian Territory changed the status of its members from that of indentured labourer on Asian rates of pay to employees enjoying permanent residency and mainland pay and conditions. This revolution was not achieved easily. In the end, however, solidarity, resolution and intelligent campaigning over a long period and a tough, competent and committed leadership won through. The Union of Christmas Island Workers story deserves to be told.

The book was actually published in 1983. It tells the complex story of the mine, how it was closed by the Government, how the workers set up a fund to reopen it and how it was adopted as a speculative enterprise by one of our beer barons-not even a Western Australian beer baron but a Victorian and multinational, or even offshore, beer baron. The Assembly bucked the Government and protested long and loud, in the first place about Australian labour at Asian rates. They protested about the running of the island by the Phosphate Mining Company for the benefit of the company. They asserted their rights as Australians. They protested about the exploitation of particularly sensitive areas of rainforest on the island. It was for all this dangerously independent thinking that the Christmas Island Assembly was dissolved by the Minister.

This is by way of background to the present situation where the Government has accepted a tender from Elders Resources Ltd, according to the Minister, because Elders Resources Ltd offered a dollar a tonne of phosphate to be set aside for the environmental rehabilitation of the mined and devastated areas of the island. I suggest that one would need a very long spoon indeed to sup with Elders. Transnational environmental sensitivity is not famous for its abundance. Ask the people of Alaska about Exxon. Look at Elders itself. It has made a very good quid indeed by running around Australia with a front-end loader and picking up whatever is not bolted down.

The Federal Government, against the opposition of the Australian Democrats and many people in the wider community, last year imposed casinos on two communities which were then without elected representation, namely, the Australian Capital Territory and Christmas Island. At that time it reviewed the arguments against casinos and the acknowledged association of casinos with organised crime in other parts of the world. In the past five years the Federal Government has conducted a number of inquiries into the future of Christmas Island. All of these inquiries advocated tourism. At the same time the Government seems to have embarked on a deliberate policy of depopulating the island, or at least replacing the islanders of Asian origin with selected white Australians. A departmental memo dated June 1988 stated:

Former Minister Brown agreed to an extension of time to commence and complete construction of the hotel casino on the basis of: the upheaval on Christmas Island with the abolition of the Christmas Island assembly and the closure of the phosphate mine; and the Department's wish to slow down development to ensure that the existing population be persuaded to leave earlier rather than later.

I repeat, to persuade the population `to leave earlier rather than later'. I remind the Senate that these people are Australian citizens on Australian territory, yet they were urged to `leave' earlier rather than later.

So what is the solution? We have a mine with only about three years of phosphate left in it, a population needing both employment and representation and a degraded and damaged but unique environment. It is not our wish to force the people of the island to leave. It is their home. We regard the Government's attempt to depopulate the island as inhumane. Last year we received a letter from Christmas Island from a social worker who explained that the English language classes introduced as part of technical and further education to the island were being discontinued. She wrote:

Is this too part of the plan to depopulate the island, or at least remove the old employees of the phosphate mine with their troublesome union and independent-minded Assembly and replace them with a more biddable group of hotel or casino employees?

The matter raised by Senator Boswell seems, to the Australian Democrats, to be an argument about which way we would prefer to be raped. A number of mining companies are arguing for a tender, fighting over the rags and bones of an island which needs not more mining but rehabilitation. Prime Minister Hawke, Minister Punch, Minister Holding and Minister Richardson have all given undertakings at various times that no more rainforests will be cleared. This undertaking must be upheld. The Australian Democrats believe that there is an alternative solution to either the massive tourist complexes involving extended airfields, gold plated facilities and casinos, on the one hand, or to phosphate mining, on the other.

Australia wishes to maintain a presence on Christmas Island. The population is fewer than 2,000. We welcome the news that the national park area of the island is to be increased from 17 per cent to 65 per cent of the island, but we are very concerned-to get down to specifics-that a number of areas of environmental significance were not included in this extension. These include the South West Terraces, which the Assembly wanted to include--

—I am sorry; I will. The point is that the Minister for the environment, with his well-known environmental sensitivity, has stated publicly that he will review these issues, and I hope that in fact he will. We wish to see the entire island given national park status. Christmas Island is a beautiful tropical island. Geographically it is part of Asia. The people there are of Chinese and Malay origin. The Muslim Malays, incidentally, are most strongly opposed to gambling, for religious reasons. From a mainland Australian point of view, this is an exotic destination. The people have exotic customs and eat exotic food, but they are all Australians. There is no need for a passport to go there; there is no need for a visa. It is one more Australian territory. It would be a good tourist destination. The keenest proponent of a Christmas Island casino has been Mr Frank Woodmore of Perth. However, I quote the following from Mr Woodmore's own prospectus for the casino development:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . even without a casino licence, Christmas Island Casino resort would be an attractive proposition. The potential for tourism is great. The visitor will discover many fascinating features on Christmas Island which cannot be found elsewhere. As a resort, the project is financially attractive.

This is from the man who wishes to develop the casino. Tourism can be both benign and financially attractive. Clearly, in the first instance, the islanders themselves must be consulted and their representative democracy returned to them. It is also no use having polls or elections if the electors are kept ignorant.

It is the view of the Australian Democrats that the first priority must be given to the preservation of the real original inhabitants of Christmas island-namely, the native bird and plant species which are presently in dire danger. I mention in particular the Christmas Island hawk owl, endemic to the island and classified as rare and endangered, and the Abbott's booby which only breeds on the island-nowhere else in the world. There are only some thousands of them left. There are even fewer of the Christmas Island frigate bird and fewer still of the golden bosun. Even the more populous species of boobies, bosuns and terns cannot withstand further incursions into their nesting areas. As well as birds there are, of course, the famous crabs as well as other species of small land animals. The crabs appear in their millions and form a tourist attraction in their own right. The recent Kew Gardens study of the botany of the island showed many rare and endangered plant species which have not even been noticed by the officers of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, let alone the boardroom operators of Elders, Booths, or Century Metals.

In conclusion, the ecosystem of Christmas Island is unique and must be preserved. The island will depend in great part on tourism for its future. These two factors must be taken into account. It is urgent that all remaining areas of rainforest be immediately included in the National Park and ultimately the whole island. The island is part of Australia and the islanders are Australians. We owe it to them as well as to ourselves to preserve this special part of our country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recognise and acknowledge that Senator Patterson has long had a keen interest in this subject. SPEECH.PARA: Having said all of that, there is a series of matters that we need to reinforce constantly in the community so there is a clearer understanding of the Government's objectives and processes. Not only do we need to say what the objectives of our program are but also we need to show as we proceed that we are meeting those objectives. It is on that basis that I stress the five key facts about the future of country nursing homes.

The first fact is that no nursing home, bush nursing home or other facility is being forced to close by the new funding arrangements. Indeed, that was referred to in the advertisement. Senator Patterson has asked at least one question about that in terms of the provision of material. I will answer that question in a moment. Secondly, the few nursing homes which are talking publicly about closing are doing so for business reasons rather than because of the new arrangements. In making broad brush statements one has to be careful that one does not miscue as to the cause of closure. Advocates wanting to proselytise in objecting to a government program concerning which they have a vested interest must be careful that they do not brandish statistics which fail to differentiate between the sources and put down bulk statistics down rather than analyse the cause, thereby presenting a false public impression. We say that the few nursing homes which are publicly talking about closing are doing so for business reasons rather than because of the new arrangements. That is an important distinction.

Thirdly, many small homes will probably choose to expand or amalgamate, and the Commonwealth will assist them to do so. That will assist the expansion of the service, which will be a laudable outcome and be seen to be so by users of the service as well as by people associated with it. Fourthly, this action will improve the viability of nursing homes and the services they provide. That speaks for itself. Fifthly, there is no reason for homes to take hasty action. Special financial assistance will be provided until 1992. For those small homes which choose to redevelop their services 1992 is three years away-or 2 1/2 years, depending on which measure one chooses to apply. That is a degree of security which should over the transitional period assuage any of the concerns that have been mentioned.

The Commonwealth Government, after all, places a high priority on ensuring that country people receive fair access to health and other services, particularly for aged people. The new funding arrangements will not be forcing the closure of any facility, as I have said. Currently a few proprietors of small nursing homes, particularly in metropolitan Melbourne, are planning to close their facilities and sell off their approved nursing home beds to other proprietors. In the past some entrepreneurs have established small nursing homes in old buildings which were inadequate to provide good quality nursing home care on a viable scale. A few of these are now proposing to close anyway. They will either transfer their operations to another location or sell their beds to other nursing home proprietors. They simply reflect business decisions taken by the entrepreneurs.

There will be no loss of nursing home beds in either metropolitan or rural areas. In fact there will be a continued expansion of total nursing home bed numbers, reflecting the Government's long term aged services plans. Previous governments have failed to plan properly for nursing homes and other aged services. As a result of that failure to plan properly, some services have developed in country areas and are operating on a scale which provides neither an efficient level of operation for the proprietor nor an adequate range of facilities and services for the residents of those homes. New Commonwealth funding arrangements will help to guarantee continued provision of services in rural areas while assisting some facilities to redevelop in order to provide both long term financial viability and an adequate range of services for their residents. TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice from Australia Post:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The NSCA (Vic) was founded in 1928 with the objective of promoting safety and preventing accidents. As a major employer concerned for the well-being of its employees, the former Postmaster-General's Department became a member. It was one of 41 organisations with the power to appoint a representative to the State Council. Australia Post inherited this membership when it was established in 1975. It has been represented on the Council for most of the time since 1975 by its state safety officers, or occupational health and safety officer. Australia Post's involvement has been related to its role as a large employer of labour, and its desire to improve safety in the workplace and the occupational health of its workers.

(2) Australia Post's involvement with the NSCA (Vic) has been related to its role as a large employer of labour and its desire to take all actions possible to improve safety in the workplace and the occupational health of its employees. It seemed appropriate, therefore, for Australia Post to be a member of the NSCA (Vic).

Australia Post's membership of the various State Divisions of the NSCA is explained in (2) above. Through its membership of the professional organisations detailed above, Australia Post is able to maintain a high profile within the business community and, in turn, be kept informed of current commercial developments and practices. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was Australia offered the opportunity to provide a senior army officer to become Commander of the Multinational Forces in the Sinai.
(2) Had approval been given for this appointment when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) vetoed the appointment.

(3) Has the appointment now gone to Lieutenant General McIver of the New Zealand Defence Force; if so, will the Minister advise why the Prime Minister has denied an Australian the chance to such valuable experience when it was at no expense to the Australian taxpayer.
(4) Were considerations of Defence Force morale and Australia's international role as a promoter of peace ignored.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The question of whether Australia might wish to be invited to nominate for the post of Commander MFO, Sinai, was raised informally late last year. This question coincided with preparations to meet our impending commitment of a 300-strong contingent to the peacekeeping force in Namibia, as well as Australia's commitment of personnel to the UN Iran/Iraq Military Observer Group and consideration of other possible peacekeeping commitments. The Government decided in view of Australia's heavy commitments to peacekeeping and monitoring forces around the world, and prospective commitments which may arise regionally, that the resumption of a contribution to the MFO Sinai was not warranted at that time.
(2) No. The Prime Minister was neither involved in this issue nor did he express any view on it to me.
(3) The position has been filled by the outgoing New Zealand Chief of the General Staff; in view of the above, further comment is redundant.

(4) No. I would like to draw the Senator's attention to the fact that the Government is committed to the promotion of peace, internationally, as most recently demonstrated by the provision of the Army contingent to the United Nations Transition Assistance Group Namibia, by far Australia's biggest peacekeeping effort to date. Australia provided 106 personnel and helicopters to the MFO from 1982 to 1986, and currently has 28 observers serving with the UN in the Middle East. The Australian Defence Force contribution in this respect is internationally recognised and appreciated as evidenced by their sharing in the Nobel Peace Prize awarded last year to peacekeepers the world over.
